item.title: The End is NIGH!
item.description:
The End is NIGH!

,,

Every week it seems that there is a new preacher, televangelist, or “numerologist” proclaiming that the end is here. If you walk around many cities or college campuses you will find someone screaming that, “The End is Nigh!”

,

It seems like everyone is looking for “the end of the world.”

,

Like we will miss it or something.

item.title: #MeToo
item.description:
#MeToo

,,

I am watching my social media feed fill with a singular hashtag, #MeToo. Friends, dear friends, are sharing it. Women in my congregation have been sexually abused or sexually harassed. I didn’t know. They had never shared that with me. Nor would I expect them too.

,

Yet, there it is, #MeToo.

item.title: Will I Learn? Will You?
item.description:
Will I Learn? Will You?

,,

Do you like to learn? I pretend to like to learn. Learning requires me to change. It demands that I do something different from what I used to do. Learning requires me to change my mind, actions, and possibly even beliefs. So, I pretend to like learning. I listen intently and nod my head at appropriate times.

,

Every once in a while go next level with a well-timed, “Hmmm…”

item.title: The Church
item.description:
The Church

,,

*NOTE: This is the fifth in a series on the Evangelical Presbyterian Church’s, The Essentials of our Faith. Scriptural proofs can be found elsewhere. These posts will focus on the “why” and the impact of these statements in our lives.

,

There are few things more messy and beautiful than the local congregation of Christians. We are a community of people who are being put back together. This means that we haven’t arrived and probably won’t arrive any time soon. Being a people under construction means that there will inevitably be failures and hurts and sin. To be a Christian means that we must be connected to the local congregation, for there is no other place to be a Christian (I’m paraphrasing Eugene Peterson here).

item.title: Master the Margins
item.description:
Master the Margins

,,

When it comes to being on mission we often miss it because we are so busy. We have little to no time to simply be with people. There is no opportunity to listen, pray, or to just look around. Every day we rush to the next place, to the next appointment, to the next meeting, or the next event. How can we possibly be on mission if there is not time or space to simply, “be”?

item.title: You Can Be Mad At God
item.description:
You Can Be Mad At God

,,

Life doesn’t always work. This world we live in is broken and messed up. People get sick. People die. Good people, really good people experience pain and suffering. We don’t often see the “why” behind what is going on. All we see is pain, sorrow, tears, brokenness, and heartache.

item.title: No Other Gospel
item.description:
No Other Gospel

,,

*NOTE: This is the fourth in a series on the Evangelical Presbyterian Church’s, The Essentials of our Faith. Scriptural proofs can be found elsewhere. These posts will focus on the “why” and the impact of these statements in our lives.

,

“Sometimes we forget the center. Sometimes we forget what it’s all about. Sometimes we forget what we are supposed to be focused on.”

,

Where do you think statement comes from? The reality is that could come from just about any pursuit that we are involved in. It could come from the director of a youth sports program. It could come from a business leader. It could come from a parent. As a pastor, I find myself thinking and saying it often about the Church.
